sn1.20:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati tapodārāme.
sn1.20:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Hot Springs Monastery.

sn1.20:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya yena tapodā tenupasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcituṃ.
sn1.20:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Samiddhi rose at the crack of dawn and went to the hot springs to bathe.
sn1.20:1.3.comm: At a later date, a deity in the same location asked Samiddhi if he knew the verses on “one fine night” (MN 133:1.3). Samiddhi further appears in discourses at MN 136, where he had gone forth only three years, and AN 9.14 , where he seems more mature. In SN 4.22, Māra threatens to shake his faith, prompting him to ask the Buddha about Māra’s true nature (SN 35.65). This event is recalled in his verse at Thag 1.46. The tale is expanded at Ja 167.

sn1.20:1.4.pli: Tapode gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsi gattāni pubbāpayamāno.
sn1.20:1.4.eng: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying his limbs.

sn1.20:1.5.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ tapodaṃ obhāsetvā yena āyasmā samiddhi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā vehāsaṃ ṭhitā āyasmantaṃ samiddhiṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn1.20:1.5.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire hot springs, went up to Samiddhi, and, standing in the air, addressed him in verse:
sn1.20:1.5.comm: The commentary says the deity is female, but he is addressed as āvuso by Samiddhi and yakkha by the Buddha, both of which are masculine.

sn1.20:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, you seek alms before you eat;

sn1.20:2.2.eng: you don’t seek alms after eating.

sn1.20:2.3.eng: But you should eat first, then seek alms:
sn1.20:2.3.comm: The deity is playing with two meanings of bhutvāna. The obvious sense is “having eaten”, because one can only eat after going for alms. By reversing the terms, they introduce a paradox—how can one eat without having obtained food?—and thereby force the second meaning of bhutvāna, “having enjoyed (the pleasures of life)”. They are suggesting that the mendicant should enjoy sensual pleasures while young, then go forth.

sn1.20:2.4.eng: don’t let the time pass you by.”

sn1.20:3.1.comm: Samiddhi joins the game, answering the deity with another play on words. He implies that “time” means the “time of death”.

sn1.20:3.3.eng: That’s why I seek alms before eating,

sn1.20:3.4.eng: so that the time may not pass me by!”

sn1.20:4.1.pli: Atha kho sā devatā pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhahitvā āyasmantaṃ samiddhiṃ etadavoca:
sn1.20:4.1.eng: Then that deity landed on the ground and said to Samiddhi,

sn1.20:4.2.pli: “daharo tvaṃ, bhikkhu, pabbajito susu kāḷakeso, bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato, paṭhamena vayasā, anikkīḷitāvī kāmesu.
sn1.20:4.2.eng: “You’ve gone forth while young, mendicant. With pristine black hair, you’re blessed with youth, in the prime of life, and you’ve never flirted with sensual pleasures.

sn1.20:4.4.eng: Don’t give up what is apparent in the present to chase after what takes effect over time.”

sn1.20:5.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvāmi.

sn1.20:5.2.pli: Kālikañca khvāhaṃ, āvuso, hitvā sandiṭṭhikaṃ anudhāvāmi.
sn1.20:5.2.eng: I’m giving up what takes effect over time to chase after what is apparent in the present.
sn1.20:5.2.comm: Similar arguments appear at SN 4.21 and MN 70:4.10.

sn1.20:5.3.pli: Kālikā hi, āvuso, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā; ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
sn1.20:5.3.eng: For the Buddha has said that sensual pleasures take effect over time, with much suffering and distress, and they’re all the more full of drawbacks.

sn1.20:5.4.pli: Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
sn1.20:5.4.eng: But this teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

sn1.20:6.1.pli: “Kathañca, bhikkhu, kālikā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo?
sn1.20:6.1.eng: “But in what way, mendicant, has the Buddha said that sensual pleasures take effect over time, with much suffering and distress, and they’re all the more full of drawbacks?

sn1.20:6.2.pli: Kathaṃ sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti?
sn1.20:6.2.eng: And how is this teaching apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”

sn1.20:7.1.pli: “Ahaṃ kho, āvuso, navo acirapabbajito adhunāgato imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ.
sn1.20:7.1.eng: “I’m junior, good fellow, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.

sn1.20:7.2.eng: I’m not able to explain this in detail.

sn1.20:7.3.pli: Ayaṃ so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho rājagahe viharati tapodārāme.
sn1.20:7.3.eng: But the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is staying near Rājagaha in the Hot Springs Monatery.

sn1.20:7.4.eng: You should go to him and ask about this matter.

sn1.20:7.5.pli: Yathā te bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāsī”ti.
sn1.20:7.5.eng: And you should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

sn1.20:8.1.pli: “Na kho, bhikkhu, sukaro so bhagavā amhehi upasaṅkamituṃ, aññāhi mahesakkhāhi devatāhi parivuto.
sn1.20:8.1.eng: “It’s not easy for us to approach the Buddha, as he is surrounded by other illustrious deities.

sn1.20:8.2.pli: Sace kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, taṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ puccheyyāsi, mayampi āgaccheyyāma dhammassavanāyā”ti.
sn1.20:8.2.eng: If you go to the Buddha and ask him about this matter, we’ll come along and listen to the teaching.”

sn1.20:8.3.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā samiddhi tassā devatāya paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā samiddhi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn1.20:8.3.eng: “Yes, reverend,” Venerable Samiddhi replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:

sn1.20:9.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya yena tapodā tenupasaṅkamiṃ gattāni parisiñcituṃ.

sn1.20:9.2.pli: Tapode gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsiṃ gattāni pubbāpayamāno.

sn1.20:9.3.pli: Atha kho, bhante, aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ tapodaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā vehāsaṃ ṭhitā imāya gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:

sn1.20:11.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, taṃ devataṃ gāthāya paccabhāsiṃ:

sn1.20:13.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sā devatā pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhahitvā maṃ etadavoca:

sn1.20:13.2.pli: ‘daharo tvaṃ, bhikkhu, pabbajito susu kāḷakeso, bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato, paṭhamena vayasā, anikkīḷitāvī kāmesu.

sn1.20:14.1.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, taṃ devataṃ etadavocaṃ:

sn1.20:14.2.pli: ‘na khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvāmi;

sn1.20:14.3.pli: kālikañca khvāhaṃ, āvuso, hitvā sandiṭṭhikaṃ anudhāvāmi.

sn1.20:14.4.pli: Kālikā hi, āvuso, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā; ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

sn1.20:14.5.pli: Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.

sn1.20:15.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sā devatā maṃ etadavoca:

sn1.20:15.2.pli: ‘kathañca, bhikkhu, kālikā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā; ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo?

sn1.20:15.3.pli: Kathaṃ sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti?

sn1.20:16.1.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, taṃ devataṃ etadavocaṃ:

sn1.20:16.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho, āvuso, navo acirapabbajito adhunāgato imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ, na tāhaṃ sakkomi vitthārena ācikkhituṃ.

sn1.20:16.3.pli: Ayaṃ so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho rājagahe viharati tapodārāme.

sn1.20:16.5.pli: Yathā te bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāsī’ti.

sn1.20:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sā devatā maṃ etadavoca:

sn1.20:17.2.pli: ‘na kho, bhikkhu, sukaro so bhagavā amhehi upasaṅkamituṃ, aññāhi mahesakkhāhi devatāhi parivuto.

sn1.20:17.3.pli: Sace kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, taṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ puccheyyāsi, mayampi āgaccheyyāma dhammassavanāyā’ti.

sn1.20:17.4.pli: Sace, bhante, tassā devatāya saccaṃ vacanaṃ, idheva sā devatā avidūre”ti.
sn1.20:17.4.eng: “Sir, if that deity spoke the truth, he’ll be close by.”

sn1.20:18.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sā devatā āyasmantaṃ samiddhiṃ etadavoca:
sn1.20:18.1.eng: When he had spoken, that deity said to Samiddhi,

sn1.20:18.2.eng: “Ask, mendicant, ask! For I have arrived.”

sn1.20:19.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ devataṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn1.20:19.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed the deity in verse:

sn1.20:20.4.eng: they fall under the yoke of Death.

sn1.20:21.1.eng: But having fully understood the communicable,

sn1.20:21.4.pli: Yena naṃ vajjā na tassa atthi;
sn1.20:21.4.eng: by which they might be described.

sn1.20:21.5.eng: Tell me if you understand, spirit.”

sn1.20:22.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, bhante, imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
sn1.20:22.1.eng: “I don’t understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

sn1.20:22.2.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tathā bhāsatu yathāhaṃ imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ jāneyyan”ti.
sn1.20:22.2.eng: Please teach me this matter so I can understand the detailed meaning.”

sn1.20:23.2.eng: special, or worse’, you’ll dispute about that.

sn1.20:23.3.eng: Unwavering in the face of the three discriminations,

sn1.20:23.4.eng: you’ll have no thought ‘I’m equal or special’.
sn1.20:23.4.comm: The third discrimination, omitted here, is “I am worse” (SN 45.162).

sn1.20:23.5.eng: Tell me if you understand, spirit.”

sn1.20:24.1.pli: “Imassapi khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa na vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
sn1.20:24.1.eng: “I don’t understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

sn1.20:24.2.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tathā bhāsatu yathāhaṃ imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ jāneyyan”ti.
sn1.20:24.2.eng: Please teach me this matter so I can understand the detailed meaning.”

sn1.20:25.1.eng: “They gave up judgement without falling into conceit;
sn1.20:25.1.comm: Saṅkhā is sometimes used in a positive senses, as one who has “appraised” the world (sn7.20:3.3]()). Here, the context suggests it means “judgements” about people (DN 1:1.4.1, MN 18).| For na vimāna read na ca māna_ per Bodhi, Connected Discourses, note 38.

sn1.20:25.2.eng: craving for name and form was cut off right here.

sn1.20:25.3.eng: They cut the ties, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope.

sn1.20:25.4.eng: Though gods and humans search for them

sn1.20:25.5.pli: Devā manussā idha vā huraṃ vā,
sn1.20:25.5.eng: in this life or the next, they never find them,

sn1.20:25.6.eng: not in heaven nor in any abode.

sn1.20:26.1.eng: Tell me if you understand, spirit.”

sn1.20:27.1.pli: “Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi—
sn1.20:27.1.eng: “This is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement:

sn1.20:28.1.eng: You should never do anything bad

sn1.20:28.2.eng: by speech or mind or body in all the world.

sn1.20:28.3.eng: Having given up sensual pleasures, <j>mindful and aware,

sn1.20:28.4.eng: you shouldn’t keep doing  <j>what’s painful and pointless.”

sn1.21:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.21:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.21:2.2.eng: like their head was on fire,

sn1.21:2.3.eng: a mendicant, mindful, should go forth,

sn1.21:2.4.comm: Here, as often (eg. AN 6.54:22.3), giving up kāmarāga implies attaining the absorptions. It cannot mean relinquishing the “underlying tendency” or the “fetter” to sensual desire, for this occurs only at the third stage of awakening (non-return), whereas the Buddha’s rejoinder urges rather to give up substantialist view, the first stage of awakening, the stream-enterer.

sn1.21:3.2.eng: like their head was on fire,

sn1.21:3.3.eng: a mendicant, mindful, should go forth,

sn1.21:3.4.comm: In some parallels for this verse, the mendicant is urged, rather, to give up desire for rebirth (Thag 1.40:1.2, Thag 20.1:24.1). But SN 2.16:3.2 is the same as here.

sn1.22:1.1.eng: “It doesn’t impact one who doesn’t impact others.
sn1.22:1.1.comm: To “impact” (phusati, elsewhere “contact” or “touch”) is to create harmful karma, which is the “it” that in turn harms the ones who impacts.

sn1.22:1.2.eng: It impacts one because they impact others.

sn1.22:1.3.eng: That’s why it impacts one who impacts,

sn1.22:1.4.eng: who wrongs one who’s done no wrong.”

sn1.22:2.1.eng: “Whoever wrongs a man who has done no wrong,
sn1.22:2.1.comm: This verse occurs with a troublesome brahmin at SN 7.4:2.1; as rejoinder to Kokālika’s attack on Sāriputta and Moggallāna at Snp 3.10:14.1 (see SN 6.10, which has the story without this verse); and at Dhp 125.

sn1.22:2.2.eng: a pure man who has not a blemish,

sn1.22:2.3.eng: the evil backfires on the fool,

sn1.23:1.1.comm: The “tangle” (jaṭā) is the tangled hair or dreadlocks of the Brahmanical jaṭila ascetics, as is made clear in SN 7.6 where a dreadlocked brahmin opens with the same verse. The claim is that jaṭila ascetics are as tangled in their minds by craving as they are in their hair.

sn1.23:1.2.eng: these people are tangled in tangles.

sn1.23:2.1.comm: In a bold literary conceit, the vast compendium of the Visuddhimagga positions itself as an explanation of this single verse.

sn1.23:2.2.comm: Here citta (“mind”) stands for samādhi or jhāna, which is normally the case in the Suttas on the path (eg. cittasampadā = samādhisampadā, cittabhāvanā = samādhibhāvanā, adhicitta = samādhi, etc.)

sn1.23:3.1.eng: Those in whom greed, hate, and ignorance
sn1.23:3.1.comm: The previous verse dealt with the one who is practicing; this verse with the perfected one; and the final verse with final extinguishment.

sn1.23:3.3.eng: the perfected ones with defilements ended—

sn1.23:4.3.eng: and impingement and perception of form:

sn1.23:4.4.eng: it’s here that the tangle is cut.”

sn1.24:1.1.comm: These are some of the very few verses in the Pali Canon whose metre has not been identified.

sn1.24:1.3.eng: So you should shield the mind from everything,

sn1.24:1.4.eng: then you’re freed from all suffering.”

sn1.24:2.1.eng: “You need not shield the mind from everything,

sn1.24:2.2.eng: nor has the mind gained self-control.

sn1.24:2.3.eng: The mind need only be shielded

sn1.24:2.4.eng: from where the bad things come.”

sn1.25:1.1.comm: Katāvī (“proficient”) is also found at MN 82:38.5.

sn1.25:1.2.eng: with defilements ended, bearing the final body:

sn1.25:1.4.comm: The questioner wonders how those who have abandoned the conceit of self could use the word “I”.

sn1.25:2.2.eng: with defilements ended, bearing the final body:

sn1.25:2.6.eng: they’d use these terms as mere expressions.”
sn1.25:2.6.comm: An “expression” (vohāra) is a “conveyance” for sharing meaning. It does not implicate the user in a metaphysical view of “Self”. See DN 9:53.5.

sn1.25:3.2.eng: with defilements ended, bearing the final body:

sn1.25:3.3.pli: Mānaṃ nu kho so upagamma bhikkhu,
sn1.25:3.3.eng: is such a mendicant drawing close to conceit

sn1.25:4.1.eng: “Someone who has given up conceit has no ties,

sn1.25:4.2.eng: the ties of conceit are all dissipated.

sn1.25:4.3.eng: Though that intelligent person has passed beyond conceiving,

sn1.25:5.3.eng: they’d use these terms as mere expressions.”

sn1.26:1.1.comm: These verses are also at SN 2.4.

sn1.26:1.3.eng: We’ve come to ask you, worthy sir:
sn1.26:1.3.comm: Accept variant bhavantaṁ in this and similar passages. Bhagavantaṁ is hypermetrical.

sn1.26:1.4.eng: how are we to understand this?”

sn1.26:2.1.eng: “There are four lamps in the world,

sn1.26:2.2.comm: With this, the Buddha contradicts Yājñavalkya, who posits two additional lights: speech (as when you can make your way in the dark by the sound of another’s voice) and the Self (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3).

sn1.26:3.3.eng: But a Buddha is the best of blazes:

sn1.27:1.1.comm: The “stream” (here sara, otherwise sota) is usually explained as craving (SN 41.5:5.10, Iti 109:3.3). Or else it could be the “stream of lives” (bhavasota) as in the next sutta (SN 1.28:2.2).

sn1.27:1.2.eng: Where does the cycle spin no more?
sn1.27:1.2.comm: The “cycle” of transmigration (saṁsāra) through endless rebirths (see DN 15:22.6, MN 22:42.2). | The “streams” and the “cycle” also occur together in Ud 7.2:4.1.

sn1.27:2.2.eng: fire and air have no footing—
sn1.27:2.2.comm: The commentary says this is Nibbāna. | A gādha is a “ford” across a river (Rig Veda 7.60.7, 7.97.8, 10.106.9; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.5.2a), a safe path on which one has a “footing” to cross the water. In this verse, the verb form gādhati means to be “established” (patiṭṭhita) like a seed in soil, or a beam of light on a floor, or consciousness in name and form.

sn1.27:2.4.eng: in reference to this, the cycle spins no more;
sn1.27:2.4.comm: Compare eg. SN 22.56:5.3, MN 22:42.2, MN 109:9.10, Ud 6.8:5.7, and DN 15:22.6.

sn1.27:2.5.eng: in reference to this, name and form

sn1.27:2.6.comm: Passages such as Snp 5.2:6.3, DN 15:22.6 and [dn11:85.26}() say that consciousness ceases at this point, too.

sn1.28:1.2.eng: even the aristocrats who rule the land,

sn1.28:2.1.eng: Among those of such an avid nature,

sn1.28:2.2.eng: flowing along the stream of lives,

sn1.28:2.3.eng: who here has given up craving?

sn1.28:2.4.eng: Who in the world is not avid?”

sn1.28:3.1.eng: “Having given up their home, their child, their cattle,

sn1.28:3.2.eng: and all that they love, they went forth.

sn1.28:3.3.eng: Having given up desire and hate,

sn1.28:3.5.eng: the perfected ones with defilements ended—

sn1.28:3.6.eng: they in the world are not avid.”

sn1.29:1.1.eng: “Four are its wheels, and nine its doors;
sn1.29:1.1.comm: These verses, with a brief setting, are also at SN 2.28:2.1. | The “four wheels” of a cart are compared to the body, but the application of the metaphor is not obvious. The commentary relates it to the four postures. Later Buddhist tantra speaks of four “wheels” (cakra) in the sense of dynamic centers of vital and spiritual energy—navel, heart, throat, crown. This is attested much later than the suttas, but this could be a precedent. | The “nine doors” are the nine apertures of the body (compare the eleven doors at MN 52:15.5).

sn1.29:1.2.eng: it’s stuffed full, bound with greed,

sn1.29:1.4.eng: Great hero, how will I keep going?”
sn1.29:1.4.comm: The phrase yātrā bhavissati is familiar from the mendicant’s reflection on eating only so that they “will keep going”. The problem here is that the body is bound up with suffering.

sn1.29:2.3.eng: and having plucked out craving, root and all:

sn1.29:2.4.eng: that’s how you will keep going.”

sn1.3:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.3:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.3:2.1.eng: “This life, so very short, is led onward.

sn1.3:2.2.eng: One led on to old age has no shelter.

sn1.3:2.4.eng: do good deeds that bring you joy.”

sn1.3:3.1.eng: “This life, so very short, is led onward;

sn1.3:3.2.eng: one led on to old age has no shelter.

sn1.3:3.4.eng: a seeker of peace would drop the world’s bait.”
sn1.3:3.4.comm: Whereas the first two discourses saw the deity asking a question, here they propose a conventional good, and the Buddha elevates it to the transcendental.
